nodes.label: Artificial Intelligence (AI)
nodes.title: Artificial Intelligence (AI)
nodes.description: Artificial Intelligence (AI):

nodes.label: Fundamental Issues
nodes.title: Fundamental Issues
nodes.description: Fundamental Issues:

nodes.label: Overview of AI problems, Examples of successful recent AI applications
nodes.title: Overview of AI problems, Examples of successful recent AI applications
nodes.description: Overview of AI problems, Examples of successful recent AI applications: AI problems encompass tasks like natural language processing, computer vision, and machine learning.

nodes.label: Definitions of agents with examples (e.g., reactive, deliberative)
nodes.title: Definitions of agents with examples (e.g., reactive, deliberative)
nodes.description: Definitions of agents with examples (e.g., reactive, deliberative): Agents are autonomous entities that perceive their environment and act upon it to achieve goals.

nodes.label: What is intelligent behavior?
nodes.title: What is intelligent behavior?
nodes.description: What is intelligent behavior?: Intelligent behavior involves the ability to adapt to new situations, solve problems, learn from experience, and achieve goals effectively.

nodes.label: The Turing test and its flaws
nodes.title: The Turing test and its flaws
nodes.description: The Turing test and its flaws: The Turing test is a measure of a machine's ability to exhibit human-like intelligence in conversation. Its flaws include the inability to assess all aspects of intelligence, such as creativity and emotional understanding, and the potential for deception by machines through narrow task-specific intelligence.

nodes.label: Multimodal input and output
nodes.title: Multimodal input and output
nodes.description: Multimodal input and output: Multimodal input refers to the use of multiple sensory channels (e.g., text, speech, image) for interaction with AI systems. Multimodal output involves presenting information or responses through various modalities (e.g., text, speech, graphics) to enhance user experience and accessibility.

nodes.label: Simulation of intelligent behavior
nodes.title: Simulation of intelligent behavior
nodes.description: Simulation of intelligent behavior: Simulation of intelligent behavior involves creating models or systems that mimic aspects of human intelligence, such as problem-solving, decision-making, and learning. I

nodes.label: Rational versus non-rational reasoning
nodes.title: Rational versus non-rational reasoning
nodes.description: Rational versus non-rational reasoning: Rational reasoning involves making decisions that maximize expected utility or achieve predefined goals based on available information. Non-rational reasoning may involve heuristics, biases, or instinctive behaviors that do not always lead to optimal outcomes, as observed in human decision-making.

nodes.label: Problem characteristics
nodes.title: Problem characteristics
nodes.description: Problem characteristics:

nodes.label: Fully versus partially observable
nodes.title: Fully versus partially observable
nodes.description: Fully versus partially observable: Fully observable problems are those where all relevant information about the current state is available to the agent. Partially observable problems are those where only a limited amount of information is available, making it necessary for the agent to maintain beliefs about the state based on available observations.

nodes.label: Single versus multi-agent
nodes.title: Single versus multi-agent
nodes.description: Single versus multi-agent: Single-agent problems involve a single autonomous entity making decisions in an environment. Multi-agent problems involve multiple autonomous entities interacting with each other and the environment, often with conflicting goals or cooperative behavior.

nodes.label: Deterministic versus stochastic
nodes.title: Deterministic versus stochastic
nodes.description: Deterministic versus stochastic: Deterministic problems have outcomes that are entirely determined by the initial state and the actions taken. Stochastic problems involve uncertainty or randomness in the outcomes, where the same action in the same state may lead to different outcomes.

nodes.label: Static versus dynamic
nodes.title: Static versus dynamic
nodes.description: Static versus dynamic: Static problems have fixed environments where the state does not change while the agent is deliberating. Dynamic problems involve environments that change over time, requiring the agent to continuously adapt its decisions in response to these changes.

nodes.label: Discrete versus continuous
nodes.title: Discrete versus continuous
nodes.description: Discrete versus continuous: Discrete problems have a finite or countably infinite set of possible states, actions, or outcomes. Continuous problems involve an infinite set of possible states, actions, or outcomes, often requiring numerical methods for representation and solution.

nodes.label: Nature of agents
nodes.title: Nature of agents
nodes.description: Nature of agents:

nodes.label: Autonomous, semi-autonomous, mixed-initiative autonomy
nodes.title: Autonomous, semi-autonomous, mixed-initiative autonomy
nodes.description: Autonomous, semi-autonomous, mixed-initiative autonomy: Agents can range from fully autonomous, making decisions independently, to semi-autonomous, requiring some human intervention, to mixed-initiative autonomy, where both the agent and human collaboratively make decisions.

nodes.label: Reflexive, goal-based, and utillity-based
nodes.title: Reflexive, goal-based, and utillity-based
nodes.description: Reflexive, goal-based, and utillity-based: Agents can exhibit different behavior paradigms, including reflexive (reactive), where actions are based on immediate sensory input; goal-based, where actions are directed towards achieving specific objectives; and utility-based, where decisions are made to maximize overall utility or satisfaction.

nodes.label: Decision making under uncertainty and with incomplete information
nodes.title: Decision making under uncertainty and with incomplete information
nodes.description: Decision making under uncertainty and with incomplete information: Agents often operate in environments with uncertain outcomes and incomplete information, requiring them to make decisions based on probabilistic reasoning and inference.

nodes.label: The importance of perception and environmental interactions
nodes.title: The importance of perception and environmental interactions
nodes.description: The importance of perception and environmental interactions: Agents rely on perception mechanisms to sense and interpret their environment, and their actions are influenced by interactions with the environment and other agents.

nodes.label: Learning-based agents
nodes.title: Learning-based agents
nodes.description: Learning-based agents: Agents can learn from past experiences and adapt their behavior over time, utilizing machine learning techniques such as reinforcement learning or supervised learning.

nodes.label: Embodied agents(sensors, dynamics, effectors)
nodes.title: Embodied agents(sensors, dynamics, effectors)
nodes.description: Embodied agents(sensors, dynamics, effectors): These agents are situated within a physical or virtual environment and interact with it through sensors and actuators, enabling them to perceive and act upon their surroundings.

nodes.label: AI Applications, growth, and Impact (economic, societal, ethics)
nodes.title: AI Applications, growth, and Impact (economic, societal, ethics)
nodes.description: AI Applications, growth, and Impact (economic, societal, ethics) : AI has witnessed significant growth and impact across various domains, including economics (automation of tasks, productivity gains), society (improved healthcare, transportation, communication), and ethics (concerns about job displacement, bias in algorithms, privacy issues).

nodes.label: Additional depth on problem characteristics with examples
nodes.title: Additional depth on problem characteristics with examples
nodes.description: Additional depth on problem characteristics with examples: Problems in AI exhibit various characteristics such as full versus partial observability, single versus multi-agent environments, deterministic versus stochastic outcomes, and static versus dynamic environments, each influencing the choice of algorithms and approaches.

nodes.label: Additional depth on nature of agents with examples
nodes.title: Additional depth on nature of agents with examples
nodes.description: Additional depth on nature of agents with examples: Agents can be further classified based on their adaptability, social intelligence, and cognitive capabilities, with examples including virtual assistants, autonomous vehicles, and recommendation systems.

nodes.label: Additional depth on AI Applications, growth, and Impact (economic, societal, ethics)
nodes.title: Additional depth on AI Applications, growth, and Impact (economic, societal, ethics)
nodes.description: Additional depth on AI Applications, growth, and Impact (economic, societal, ethics): AI applications extend beyond traditional domains into areas like environmental conservation, disaster response, and personalized education, raising questions about fairness, accountability, and transparency in AI systems.

nodes.label: Search
nodes.title: Search
nodes.description: Search:

nodes.label: State space representation of a problem
nodes.title: State space representation of a problem
nodes.description: State space representation of a problem: Problems are represented using states, goals, and operators, defining the initial and desired states and the actions that transition between states.

nodes.label: Specifying states, goals, and operators
nodes.title: Specifying states, goals, and operators
nodes.description: Specifying states, goals, and operators:

nodes.label: Factoring states intrepresentations (hypothesis spaces)
nodes.title: Factoring states intrepresentations (hypothesis spaces)
nodes.description: Factoring states intrepresentations (hypothesis spaces): States are often factored into representations to simplify problem-solving, creating a hypothesis space of possible solutions.

nodes.label: Problem solving by graph search
nodes.title: Problem solving by graph search
nodes.description: Problem solving by graph search: e.g., Graphs as a space, and tree traversals as exploration of that space; Dynamic construction of the graph

nodes.label: Uninformed graph search for problem solving
nodes.title: Uninformed graph search for problem solving
nodes.description: Uninformed graph search for problem solving:

nodes.label: Breadth-first search
nodes.title: Breadth-first search
nodes.description: Breadth-first search: Breadth-First Search (BFS): Explores the search graph level by level, expanding all nodes at each level before moving to the next level, ensuring the shortest path to the goal is found.

nodes.label: Depth-first search(With iterative deepening)
nodes.title: Depth-first search(With iterative deepening)
nodes.description: Depth-first search(With iterative deepening): Depth-First Search (DFS): Explores the search graph by going as deep as possible along each branch before backtracking, potentially getting stuck in deep branches and not guaranteeing optimality.

nodes.label: Uniform cost search
nodes.title: Uniform cost search
nodes.description: Uniform cost search: Uniform Cost Search: Expands the node with the lowest path cost, ensuring optimality in finding the lowest-cost path to the goal, similar to BFS but considering path cost instead of depth.

nodes.label: Heuristic graph search for problem solving
nodes.title: Heuristic graph search for problem solving
nodes.description: Heuristic graph search for problem solving: Heuristic Graph Search for Problem Solving: Utilizes domain-specific heuristics to guide the search process towards the goal state more efficiently, often used when the search space is too large for uninformed search methods.

nodes.label: Heuristic construction and admissibility
nodes.title: Heuristic construction and admissibility
nodes.description: Heuristic construction and admissibility : Heuristic Construction and Admissibility: Heuristics are designed to estimate the cost or distance from a given state to the goal state while adhering to admissibility, ensuring that the heuristic never overestimates the true cost.

nodes.label: Hill-climbing
nodes.title: Hill-climbing
nodes.description: Hill-climbing: Hill-Climbing: An iterative search algorithm that continuously moves towards the direction of increasing heuristic value, potentially getting stuck in local optima due to its greedy nature.

nodes.label: Local minima and the search landscape(Local vs global solutions)
nodes.title: Local minima and the search landscape(Local vs global solutions)
nodes.description: Local minima and the search landscape(Local vs global solutions):  Local minima are states where no neighboring states have lower heuristic values, potentially trapping hill-climbing algorithms. Global solutions are optimal solutions found by considering the entire search space.

nodes.label: Greedy best-first search
nodes.title: Greedy best-first search
nodes.description: Greedy best-first search: Expands nodes based on their heuristic values alone, always choosing the node that appears to be closest to the goal without considering the cost of the path to reach that node.

nodes.label: A* search
nodes.title: A* search
nodes.description: A* search:  A combination of uniform cost search and greedy best-first search, evaluates nodes based on both the cost of the path from the start node and the estimated cost to the goal

nodes.label: Space and time complexities of graph search algorithms
nodes.title: Space and time complexities of graph search algorithms
nodes.description: Space and time complexities of graph search algorithms: The space complexity refers to the amount of memory required by the algorithm, while the time complexity measures the computational resources required, typically expressed in terms of the number of nodes expanded or visited.

nodes.label: Bidirectional search
nodes.title: Bidirectional search
nodes.description: Bidirectional search: Utilizes two simultaneous searches, one from the start node and the other from the goal node, meeting in the middle to find the shortest path. It reduces the search space and time complexity compared to uninformed graph search algorithms.

nodes.label: Beam search
nodes.title: Beam search
nodes.description: Beam search: A heuristic search algorithm that explores a limited set of most promising paths, known as the beam width or beam size. It focuses on breadth rather than depth, often used in problems where the goal state is not well-defined or when the search space is too large.

nodes.label: Two-player adversarial games
nodes.title: Two-player adversarial games
nodes.description: Two-player adversarial games: Involves two players with opposing objectives, such as in chess or tic-tac-toe. Minimax search is a decision-making algorithm used to determine the optimal move for one player while considering the possible moves and counter-moves of the opponent.

nodes.label: Minimax search
nodes.title: Minimax search
nodes.description: Minimax search: A decision-making algorithm used in two-player adversarial games to maximize the minimum possible outcome for the player while minimizing the maximum possible outcome for the opponent.

nodes.label: Alpha-beta pruning(Ply cutoff)
nodes.title: Alpha-beta pruning(Ply cutoff)
nodes.description: Alpha-beta pruning(Ply cutoff): An optimization technique used in the minimax algorithm to reduce the number of nodes evaluated, achieved by pruning branches of the search tree that are guaranteed to be worse than previously examined branches.

nodes.label: Fundamental Knowledge Representation and Reasoning
nodes.title: Fundamental Knowledge Representation and Reasoning
nodes.description: Fundamental Knowledge Representation and Reasoning:

nodes.label: Types of representations
nodes.title: Types of representations
nodes.description: Types of representations: Knowledge can be represented symbolically, using logical statements or rules, or through learned subsymbolic representations, such as neural network weights.

nodes.label: Symbolic, logical
nodes.title: Symbolic, logical
nodes.description: Symbolic, logical:

nodes.label: Learned subsymbolic representations
nodes.title: Learned subsymbolic representations
nodes.description: Learned subsymbolic representations:

nodes.label: Graphical models(e.g., naive Bayes, Bayes net)
nodes.title: Graphical models(e.g., naive Bayes, Bayes net)
nodes.description: Graphical models(e.g., naive Bayes, Bayes net): Graphical models like naive Bayes and Bayes nets provide a graphical representation of relationships between variables.

nodes.label: Review of probabilistic reasoning, Bayes theorem
nodes.title: Review of probabilistic reasoning, Bayes theorem
nodes.description: Review of probabilistic reasoning, Bayes theorem: Probability theory is used to reason about uncertainty. Bayes' theorem provides a way to update beliefs based on new evidence.

nodes.label: Bayesian reasoning
nodes.title: Bayesian reasoning
nodes.description: Bayesian reasoning:

nodes.label: Bayesian inference
nodes.title: Bayesian inference
nodes.description: Bayesian inference: Involves using Bayes' theorem to update the probability of a hypothesis based on observed evidence.

nodes.label: Random variables and probability distributions
nodes.title: Random variables and probability distributions
nodes.description: Random variables and probability distributions: Random variables represent uncertain quantities, and probability distributions describe how likely different values of a random variable are.

nodes.label: Axioms of probability
nodes.title: Axioms of probability
nodes.description: Axioms of probability: Probability theory is based on a set of axioms that define how probabilities must behave.

nodes.label: Probabilistic inference
nodes.title: Probabilistic inference
nodes.description: Probabilistic inference: Involves using probability distributions to compute the probability of different hypotheses or events given observed evidence.

nodes.label: Bayes’ Rule (derivation)
nodes.title: Bayes’ Rule (derivation)
nodes.description: Bayes’ Rule (derivation): Bayes' rule is derived from the definition of conditional probability and allows for the calculation of the probability of a hypothesis given observed evidence.

nodes.label: Bayesian inference (more complex examples)
nodes.title: Bayesian inference (more complex examples)
nodes.description: Bayesian inference (more complex examples):

nodes.label: Independence
nodes.title: Independence
nodes.description: Independence: Two events are independent if the occurrence of one does not affect the occurrence of the other.

nodes.label: Conditional Independence
nodes.title: Conditional Independence
nodes.description: Conditional Independence: Conditional independence describes the independence of two events given the occurrence of a third event.

nodes.label: Utility and decision making
nodes.title: Utility and decision making
nodes.description: Utility and decision making: In decision theory, utility functions represent preferences over outcomes, and decision-making involves choosing actions that maximize expected utility.

nodes.label: Machine Learning
nodes.title: Machine Learning
nodes.description: Machine Learning:

nodes.label: Definition and examples of a broad variety of machine learning tasks
nodes.title: Definition and examples of a broad variety of machine learning tasks
nodes.description: Definition and examples of a broad variety of machine learning tasks:

nodes.label: Supervised learning
nodes.title: Supervised learning
nodes.description: Supervised learning: In supervised learning, the model learns from labeled data, where each example is associated with a target label. Classification tasks involve predicting categorical labels, while regression tasks involve predicting continuous values.

nodes.label: Classification
nodes.title: Classification
nodes.description: Classification: Involves categorizing data into predefined classes or categories based on their features.

nodes.label: Regression
nodes.title: Regression
nodes.description: Regression: Predicts continuous numerical outcomes by establishing a relationship between independent and dependent variables.

nodes.label: Reinforcement learning
nodes.title: Reinforcement learning
nodes.description: Reinforcement learning: Reinforcement learning involves learning to make decisions by interacting with an environment and receiving feedback in the form of rewards or penalties.

nodes.label: Unsupervised learning
nodes.title: Unsupervised learning
nodes.description: Unsupervised learning: Unsupervised learning deals with unlabeled data and aims to find hidden patterns or structures within the data. Clustering algorithms group similar data points together.

nodes.label: Clustering
nodes.title: Clustering
nodes.description: Clustering: Groups similar data points together based on their inherent characteristics or similarities without prior knowledge of class labels.

nodes.label: Fundamental ideas(no free lunch; undecidability; sources of error in machine learning)
nodes.title: Fundamental ideas(no free lunch; undecidability; sources of error in machine learning)
nodes.description: Fundamental ideas(no free lunch; undecidability; sources of error in machine learning): The "no free lunch" theorem suggests that there is no one-size-fits-all algorithm that performs best on all problems. Undecidability refers to the fact that some problems in machine learning are inherently unsolvable. Sources of error in machine learning include bias, variance, and irreducible error.

nodes.label: Simple statistical-based supervised learning such as Naive Bayes, Decision trees
nodes.title: Simple statistical-based supervised learning such as Naive Bayes, Decision trees
nodes.description: Simple statistical-based supervised learning such as Naive Bayes, Decision trees: Examples include Naive Bayes, which is based on Bayes' theorem and assumes independence between features, and decision trees, which recursively split the data based on feature values.

nodes.label: The overfitting problem and controlling solution complexity (regularization, pruning – intuition only)
nodes.title: The overfitting problem and controlling solution complexity (regularization, pruning – intuition only)
nodes.description: The overfitting problem and controlling solution complexity (regularization, pruning – intuition only): Overfitting occurs when a model learns the training data too well and performs poorly on unseen data. Techniques such as regularization and pruning are used to control the complexity of the model and prevent overfitting.

nodes.label: The bias (underfitting) - variance (overfitting) tradeoff
nodes.title: The bias (underfitting) - variance (overfitting) tradeoff
nodes.description: The bias (underfitting) - variance (overfitting) tradeoff: The bias-variance tradeoff refers to the balance between a model's ability to capture the true relationship in the data (bias) and its sensitivity to fluctuations in the training data (variance). Underfitting occurs when the model is too simple to capture the underlying structure of the data (high bias), while overfitting occurs when the model fits the noise in the training data (high variance). Balancing bias and variance is crucial for building models that generalize well to unseen data.

nodes.label: Working with Data
nodes.title: Working with Data
nodes.description: Working with Data:

nodes.label: Data preprocessing
nodes.title: Data preprocessing
nodes.description: Data preprocessing: Before feeding data into machine learning models, it often requires preprocessing steps such as handling missing values and encoding categorical variables.

nodes.label: Handling missing values (imputing,flag-as-missing)
nodes.title: Handling missing values (imputing,flag-as-missing)
nodes.description: Handling missing values (imputing,flag-as-missing): Techniques include imputing missing values by replacing them with statistical measures (e.g., mean, median) or flagging them as missing to preserve information.

nodes.label: Encoding categorical variables, encoding real-valued data
nodes.title: Encoding categorical variables, encoding real-valued data
nodes.description: Encoding categorical variables, encoding real-valued data: Categorical variables need to be converted into numerical representations for machine learning algorithms to process them effectively.

nodes.label: Normalization/standardization
nodes.title: Normalization/standardization
nodes.description: Normalization/standardization: Scaling features to a similar range can help improve the performance of some machine learning algorithms.

nodes.label: Emphasis on real data, not textbook examples
nodes.title: Emphasis on real data, not textbook examples
nodes.description: Emphasis on real data, not textbook examples:

nodes.label: Representations
nodes.title: Representations
nodes.description: Representations:

nodes.label: Hypothesis spaces and complexity
nodes.title: Hypothesis spaces and complexity
nodes.description: Hypothesis spaces and complexity: The choice of hypothesis space, which defines the set of possible models, and its complexity affect the model's ability to learn and generalize from data.

nodes.label: Simple basis feature expansion, such as squaring univariate features
nodes.title: Simple basis feature expansion, such as squaring univariate features
nodes.description: Simple basis feature expansion, such as squaring univariate features: Transforming input features by expanding them, such as squaring univariate features, can enable models to capture more complex relationships in the data.

nodes.label: Learned feature representations
nodes.title: Learned feature representations
nodes.description: Learned feature representations: In deep learning and other advanced techniques, models can automatically learn hierarchical representations of data, potentially capturing intricate patterns that may not be apparent in the original features.

nodes.label: Machine learning evaluation
nodes.title: Machine learning evaluation
nodes.description: Machine learning evaluation:

nodes.label: Separation of train, validation, and test sets
nodes.title: Separation of train, validation, and test sets
nodes.description: Separation of train, validation, and test sets: Data is typically divided into three sets: training set for model training, validation set for parameter tuning and model selection, and test set for evaluating the final model's performance on unseen data.

nodes.label: Performance metrics for classifiers
nodes.title: Performance metrics for classifiers
nodes.description: Performance metrics for classifiers: Various metrics such as accuracy, precision, recall, F1-score, and ROC curve are used to assess the performance of classifiers based on their predictions.

nodes.label: Estimation of test performance on held-out data
nodes.title: Estimation of test performance on held-out data
nodes.description: Estimation of test performance on held-out data: The test set is used to estimate the final performance of the model, providing an unbiased evaluation of its generalization ability to unseen data.

nodes.label: Tuning the parameters of a machine learning model with a validation set
nodes.title: Tuning the parameters of a machine learning model with a validation set
nodes.description: Tuning the parameters of a machine learning model with a validation set: Hyperparameters of machine learning models are tuned using the validation set to optimize performance without overfitting to the test set.

nodes.label: Importance of understanding what your model is actually doing, where its pitfalls/shortcomings are, and the implications of its decisions
nodes.title: Importance of understanding what your model is actually doing, where its pitfalls/shortcomings are, and the implications of its decisions
nodes.description: Importance of understanding what your model is actually doing, where its pitfalls/shortcomings are, and the implications of its decisions:

nodes.label: Basic neural networks
nodes.title: Basic neural networks
nodes.description: Basic neural networks:

nodes.label: Fundamentals of understanding how neural networks work and their training process, without details of the calculations
nodes.title: Fundamentals of understanding how neural networks work and their training process, without details of the calculations
nodes.description: Fundamentals of understanding how neural networks work and their training process, without details of the calculations: Gain an understanding of how neural networks function and the overall process of training them, focusing on high-level concepts rather than detailed calculations.

nodes.label: Ethics for Machine Learning
nodes.title: Ethics for Machine Learning
nodes.description: Ethics for Machine Learning:

nodes.label: Focus on real data, real scenarios, and case studies.
nodes.title: Focus on real data, real scenarios, and case studies.
nodes.description: Focus on real data, real scenarios, and case studies.: Emphasize the ethical considerations surrounding machine learning in real-world contexts, discussing case studies and practical applications to highlight ethical challenges and dilemmas.

nodes.label: Dataset/algorithmic/evaluation bias
nodes.title: Dataset/algorithmic/evaluation bias
nodes.description: Dataset/algorithmic/evaluation bias: Explore the concept of bias in machine learning, including biases present in datasets, algorithms, and evaluation metrics, and discuss strategies for identifying, mitigating, and addressing bias to ensure fairness and equity in machine learning systems.

nodes.label: Formulation of simple machine learning as an optimization problem, such as least squares linear regression or logistic regression
nodes.title: Formulation of simple machine learning as an optimization problem, such as least squares linear regression or logistic regression
nodes.description: Formulation of simple machine learning as an optimization problem, such as least squares linear regression or logistic regression:

nodes.label: Gradient descent
nodes.title: Gradient descent
nodes.description: Gradient descent: Learn about gradient descent, a common optimization algorithm used to minimize the objective function by iteratively adjusting model parameters in the direction of the steepest descent of the objective function.

nodes.label: Regularization tavoid overfitting (mathematical formulation)
nodes.title: Regularization tavoid overfitting (mathematical formulation)
nodes.description: Regularization tavoid overfitting (mathematical formulation): Explore regularization techniques, such as L1 and L2 regularization, which are used to prevent overfitting by penalizing large parameter values in the optimization process.

nodes.label: Ensembles of models
nodes.title: Ensembles of models
nodes.description: Ensembles of models:

nodes.label: Simple weighted majority combination
nodes.title: Simple weighted majority combination
nodes.description: Simple weighted majority combination: Understand the concept of ensemble learning, where multiple models are combined to improve predictive performance.

nodes.label: Deep learning
nodes.title: Deep learning
nodes.description: Deep learning:

nodes.label: Deep feed-forward networks (intuition only, nmath)
nodes.title: Deep feed-forward networks (intuition only, nmath)
nodes.description: Deep feed-forward networks (intuition only, nmath): Gain intuition about deep feed-forward neural networks, also known as multilayer perceptrons, which consist of multiple layers of interconnected neurons. Understand their architecture and basic functioning without delving into detailed mathematics.

nodes.label: Convolutional neural networks (intuition only, nmath)
nodes.title: Convolutional neural networks (intuition only, nmath)
nodes.description: Convolutional neural networks (intuition only, nmath): Explore convolutional neural networks (CNNs) intuitively, focusing on their hierarchical structure and ability to capture spatial hierarchies of features in data like images.

nodes.label: Visualization of learned feature representations from deep nets
nodes.title: Visualization of learned feature representations from deep nets
nodes.description: Visualization of learned feature representations from deep nets: Learn about techniques to visualize and interpret the learned representations of data by deep neural networks

nodes.label: Performance evaluation
nodes.title: Performance evaluation
nodes.description: Performance evaluation:

nodes.label: Other metrics for classification
nodes.title: Other metrics for classification
nodes.description: Other metrics for classification : Explore additional evaluation metrics for classification tasks beyond accuracy. e.g.,error, precision, recall

nodes.label: Performance metrics for regressors
nodes.title: Performance metrics for regressors
nodes.description: Performance metrics for regressors: Understand evaluation metrics specific to regression tasks, including mean squared error (MSE), mean absolute error (MAE), and R-squared.

nodes.label: Confusion matrix
nodes.title: Confusion matrix
nodes.description: Confusion matrix: Learn about the confusion matrix as a tool for evaluating the performance of a classification algorithm by summarizing the counts of true positive, true negative, false positive, and false negative predictions.

nodes.label: Cross-validation
nodes.title: Cross-validation
nodes.description: Cross-validation: Explore cross-validation techniques such as k-fold cross-validation and leave-one-out cross-validation for estimating the performance of machine learning models on unseen data.

nodes.label: Parameter tuning (grid/random search, via cross-validation)
nodes.title: Parameter tuning (grid/random search, via cross-validation)
nodes.description: Parameter tuning (grid/random search, via cross-validation):

nodes.label: Overview of reinforcement learning
nodes.title: Overview of reinforcement learning
nodes.description: Overview of reinforcement learning:

nodes.label: Twor more applications of machine learning algorithms
nodes.title: Twor more applications of machine learning algorithms
nodes.description: Twor more applications of machine learning algorithms: E.g., medicine and health, economics, vision, natural language, robotics, game play

nodes.label: Ethics for Machine Learning
nodes.title: Ethics for Machine Learning
nodes.description: Ethics for Machine Learning: Continued focus on real data, real scenarios, and case studies; Privacy; Fairness

nodes.label: Applications and Societal Impact
nodes.title: Applications and Societal Impact
nodes.description: Applications and Societal Impact:

nodes.label: Applications of AI ta broad set of problems and diverse fields, such as medicine, health, sustainability, social media, economics, education, robotics, etc.
nodes.title: Applications of AI ta broad set of problems and diverse fields, such as medicine, health, sustainability, social media, economics, education, robotics, etc.
nodes.description: Applications of AI ta broad set of problems and diverse fields, such as medicine, health, sustainability, social media, economics, education, robotics, etc. : Explore the wide-ranging applications of artificial intelligence (AI) in various domains, including medicine, healthcare, sustainability, social media, economics, education, robotics, and more.

nodes.label: Formulating and evaluating a specific application as an AI problem
nodes.title: Formulating and evaluating a specific application as an AI problem
nodes.description: Formulating and evaluating a specific application as an AI problem: Learn how to formulate real-world problems as AI tasks, considering factors such as problem definition, data availability, and desired outcomes

nodes.label: Data availability and cleanliness
nodes.title: Data availability and cleanliness
nodes.description: Data availability and cleanliness: Basic data cleaning and preprocessing, Data set bias

nodes.label: Algorithmic bias
nodes.title: Algorithmic bias
nodes.description: Algorithmic bias: Examine the issue of algorithmic bias, where AI systems may produce unfair or discriminatory outcomes due to biases present in the training data or model design.

nodes.label: Evaluation bias
nodes.title: Evaluation bias
nodes.description: Evaluation bias: Discuss the concept of evaluation bias, where the metrics used to assess AI systems may not accurately reflect their real-world performance or impact.

nodes.label: Deployed deep generative models
nodes.title: Deployed deep generative models
nodes.description: Deployed deep generative models:

nodes.label: High-level overview of deep image generative models
nodes.title: High-level overview of deep image generative models
nodes.description: High-level overview of deep image generative models: (e.g. as of 2023, DALL-E, Midjourney, Stable Diffusion, etc.), how they work, their uses, and their shortcomings/pitfalls.

nodes.label: High-level overview of large language models
nodes.title: High-level overview of large language models
nodes.description: High-level overview of large language models: (e.g. as of 2023, ChatGPT, Bard, etc.), how they work, their uses, and their shortcomings/pitfalls.

nodes.label: Societal impact of AI
nodes.title: Societal impact of AI
nodes.description: Societal impact of AI: Ethics, Fairness, Trust/explainability
